topics.body: Apparently, TMNT is not as bad as everyone thought... Personally though,that doesn't tell me anything

"@mariomarc":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/53e452f563687230293f0100#post_53e452f563687230293f0100
[bq="mariomarc"]depends what the aliens look like

like i mean are they humanoid?
or just pile of guts and slime
like Jaba[/bq]
It depends on what planet they're from and whether or not they're fully organic/synthetic lifeforms.

My guess is that is first contact will be 1)finding bacteria in our own solar system, probably europa 2)finding radio signals from another solar system 3)contact from synthetic lifeforms.

1)Europa is our best bet.
2)By the time we receive the radio signals they're probably long gone or have moved away; still the technological advancements from learning from their broadcasts would advance us by leaps and bounds.
3)Chances are type 1/2/3 civilizations are primarily synthetic lifeforms.  What I mean by this is that there are massive physical limitations of organic biology such as we can't breath in space.  Synthetic lifeforms it's merely a engineering problem.  I don't mean that in the traditional scifi Ai sense, but rather organisms that make biologists and computer engineers bash their brains out trying to understand how a machine can be alive.
